brief_description of the content in the: The source page describes a rule that identifies calls to Assert.assertEquals(), Assert.assertTrue(), and similar methods that can be migrated to the Hamcrest declarative style Assert.assertThat() calls. It also provides a quick-fix to perform this migration.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'migrateAssertToMatcherAssert' checks all classes and their methods. If a method contains calls to 'Assert.assertEquals' or 'Assert.assertTrue', it asserts that the same method does not contain a call to 'Assert.assertThat'. If the assertion fails, it generates a message indicating that the method can be migrated to use 'Assert.assertThat' in Hamcrest declarative style.
PRE_model_validation: The rule uses built-in functions such as 'getClasses', 'getMethods', 'callExists', 'getName', and 'getFQN'. It does not introduce any new built-in functions. The rule follows the syntax of RSL and does not contain any comments or BOM.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. URL: https://www.baeldung.com/hamcrest-collections-array - This page provides a detailed guide on using Hamcrest for assertions in JUnit tests, including the use of 'Assert.assertThat'.
2. URL: https://www.javacodegeeks.com/2015/11/why-we-should-love-hamcrests-assertthat.html - This page explains the benefits of using 'Assert.assertThat' over traditional JUnit assertions like 'Assert.assertEquals' and 'Assert.assertTrue'.
